awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER award funds the research and outreach activities of Professor Stefania Gori at the University of Cincinnati.
 
Particle physics faces two fundamental problems that point to "new physics" lying beyond our current understanding.   The first of these is the existence of a relatively light so-called Higgs boson, as discovered by the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in 2012.   The biggest mystery here is to explain the origin of the mass of this new particle.   The second fundamental problem is to understand the nature and origin of the so-called "dark matter" that is five times more prevalent throughout the universe than ordinary matter. One possibility is that dark matter can arise together with a completely new sector of dark particles which have not been discovered by experiments conducted thus far because such particles are presumed to interact only very weakly with the known particles.  As part of her proposed research, Professor Gori will pursue an ambitious research program focused on studying these two fundamental problems at the interface between high-energy and high-intensity experiments. She will explore new models with more than one Higgs boson and investigate extended dark-sector theories.   As part of her work, she will also develop new search strategies for existing and planned experiments at Fermilab and extend its science mission with searches for dark particles.  As such, Professor Gori's research furthers the national interest by advancing our understanding of the fundamental laws of nature and potentially enhancing the research done at one of the premier US national laboratories. Professor Gori will also initiate an outreach program aimed at underrepresented minorities (URMs), connecting the University of Cincinnati Physics Department with local high schools and elementary schools whose student populations are majority female or African-American.  In particular, she will start a "Women in STEM: From High School to Academia" program, and she will broaden the after-school programs of local schools with predominantly URM student bodies. 
 
More technically, Professor Gori will build new models of extended sectors responsible for quark and lepton masses, and explore the signatures of such models at both low- and high-energy experiments, focusing on the connection between Higgs and flavor physics. Professor Gori will develop new search strategies for light dark sectors at existing and planned experiments at Fermilab: MINOS+, NOvA and the DUNE near detectors, and the SeaQuest nuclear physics experiment. This will allow searches for a vast set of dark-sector theories. Professor Gori will also work closely with the experimental collaborations to explore optimized setups for DUNE and SeaQuest to maximize their physics reach. Professor Gori will also exploit the connection between the Higgs and dark sectors in order to develop scenarios in which dark-sector particles are produced from Higgs decays, leading to novel signatures that can investigated over the coming years at the LHC.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant supported the research program of principal investigator (PI) Stefania Gori. The research was conducted in collaboration with post-docs, graduate and undergraduate students and explored answers to two fundamental problems that point to "New physics" beyond the Standard Model: the existence of a relatively light Higgs boson, as discovered by the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in 2012, and the origin of a new form of matter, the "dark matter". Dark matter can arise together with a completely new sector of dark particles, not yet discovered by the experiments conducted so far because very weakly interacting with the known particles. 

Professor Gori pursued an ambitious research program that resulted in three major outcomes:

(1) New models with more than one Higgs boson have been investigated. This resulted in new proposed signatures that the LHC collaborations can look for in the coming years. Models with additional Higgs bosons generically contain new sources of CP violation that contribute to electric dipole moments (EDMs). In this context, the PI finalized the first complete two-loop calculation of the electron and light quark EDMs in a model with two Higgs doublets.

(2) The cosmology and phenomenology of dark sector theories have been explored. This resulted in the development of new search strategies for existing and planned experiments at Fermilab, extending their science mission with searches for dark particles. The PI has spearheaded the dark sector activities of the SeaQuest experiment and its future upgrade (the DarkQuest experiment). She also explored discovery prospects for axion-like particles and new gauge bosons at meson factories and other high-intensity experiments, like the Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE).

(3) The status of the LHC program for Higgs exotic decays was reassessed in a review article that the PI co-authored. This work represents the first complete assessment of the field of Higgs exotic decays after the initial review that the PI co-authored in 2014. The new study clearly shows the progress in the past eight years and the future goals to achieve a deeper understanding of Higgs exotic decays and of dark sector models that can be tested by searching for Higgs exotic decays.

Professor Gori also initiated a broader impact program at UCSC aimed at underrepresented minorities. She led several outreach activities in the context of the `Women in STEM: from high school to academia" program, and she contributed to engaging the local community. She trained and mentored a broad range of students and junior researchers. The exploration of models with new Higgs bosons became the thesis topic of the PI's first Ph.D. student, who graduated at the end of the second year of this project. Several junior researchers supported by the NSF grant moved to professorship positions at leading universities and research laboratories.
